Good take on the style form a brewery not usually known for sticking to style.

22oz bottle acquired in trade with Acknud.  An awesome Helles Lager.  Poured a mostly clear golden yellow with a big ol fizzy white head.  A lot fruit and malt in the nose than your standard lager.  Finish was crisp, clean and even a little fruity.  Another great one from FFF.

Hazy pale yellow. Large white head all but vanishes into a fine white ring. Pilsner malt yields an abundance of fresh hay and toasted dough aromatics. Very minerally with hints of honey, plastic and herbal hops (aniseed, sage). Plentiful carbonation harshly pricks the palate and deposits a slightly fuzzy residue. Body is full and unfiltered. Quenching acidity greets the palate before an onset of sharp plasticy phenols lends a scrubbing action. Slightly tinny though the full and well-rounded malt develops a vivid breadiness which smothers the phenols as it gradually softens. Brisk minerals are accompanied by a delectable bite of snappy pistachio-tinged yeastiness. Herbal hops are tightly integrated and beautifully lend their poignantly defined crispness and juiciness to the pillowy malt frame. Dab of caramelized sugars exudes briefly but the malt largely mimics notes and textures of damp honey-drizzled hay. Pils malt is voluptuously starchy and clingy and is highlighted by a lemony accent. The clean finish boasts a steady and lush foundation of toasted dough which lingers. Praise be to Ninkasi that they didnt filter this. Its just too bad about the harsh and acidic carbonation as it inhibits the cleanly extracted malt from fully capturing the spotlight.  The phenols add an interesting element, and impart more liveliness rather than becoming too much of a detraction to me. Quality stuff.
user_location: Blue Ridge Mountains, North Carolina, USA

text: Bomber courtesy of tjthresh. Pours a hazy, light straw with a dense, frothy, white head that diminishes to a thin cap of bubbles. It smells of hay, sweet malt and faint grassy hops. The palate is light-bodied and soft with fine carbonation and a lightly dry, crisp finish. Lightly sweet barley malt fronts a flavor that is fairly simple but very clean. Also present are faint notes of lemon, plain Italian bread and lightly grassy hops. This is a very drinkable and refreshing brew, but @ $9 a bomber, I doubt that Ill be revisiting it any time soon. Thanks for hauling this one back from the Hoosier state, Tom. :)

22 oz bottle
I am not sure what I was expecting when I cracked open the bottle but this was not it.  After some adjustment I began to enjoy the contents.  Unfortunately it was a bit of a letdown.  At $5.00 it wasnt a total waste though I can think of other beers I would choose instead.  Pass on this one unless you really must try every 3F release.
Aroma / Appearance - The transparent golden body had a nice carbonation that showed there was still life to the contents.  A one finger bleached white head sat above.  Graininess, honey and malts formed a nose that I found far too simplistic even for a dortmunder. Imagine eating a slice of white bread without any toppings.
Flavor / Palate - Golden grahams, honey and a light maltiness rush across the tongue in an attempt to disappear quickly.  It was predictable and somewhat boring.  Perhaps this is Three Floyds version of Totally Naked - a beer that is reliable, safe and approachable by people used to Budweiser.  That audience does not include me.

A buddy of mine brought back from Munster. Pours a strawish yellow with almost no head. Aroma is of hay, bread, and grassy and lemon flavored hops. Light bread, grass, straw, with a light hop finish. Pretty crisp. Clean and pleasant. Pretty light. Well made, but not alot going on.

Bottle (22oz) shared with HogTownHarry & tupalev -- courtesy of HogTownHarry. Pours a hazy pale yellow-gold with a small diminishing white head. Aroma smells nice, quite fruity, with a good amount of hops, a little spicy and some yeast. Flavour: Pretty tasty stuff, fruity along with spicy hops, yeast and light malt -- a touch watery but pretty easy to drink. Average to medium bodied. For a beer thats not a favourite style of mine this is really good, Id happily drink this again!

Deep yellow in color the beer poued almost no head and didnt leave any lacing though bubbles did continue to rise throughout drinking.  The nose showed scents of lemon, orange peel, pumpkin and some spices.  In the mouth this beer starts off light and effervescent before filling out just a touch more in the midpalate.  It remains tart, dry and refreshing though there is very good balancing sweetness through the midpalate and finish.  Rather simple but very drinkable and enjoyable however not worth the money.  The Gumballhead fits the same drinking occasions, is much cheaper and a better beer.

Bottle shared with Hogtown Harry and Blankboy, courtesy of Harry.  Dark yellow, small white head.  Nice aroma - lots of hops, yeast, some light lemon - very nice.  Good taste - again, hops, lots of lemon, medium body.  Very refreshing and drinkable and from my limited knowledge, a good example of the style.

Bottle (22oz).  Shared with blankboy and tupalev, my bottle courtesy of LagerLoather.  Hazy yellow pour, average white head.  Aroma is lemony and grassy, a little sweet.  Taste is hoppier - grassy hops, lemon and light.  Light body, nice astringency, midly acidic in the finish.  Pretty decent.
Bottle.  Sour barley malt aroma.  Hazy yellow color with minimal head.  Nice strong barley malt flavor with just a hint of hops.  An excellent example of the style.
A nice, if less than overwhelming helles.  Good color and flavor, but nothing extraordinary.  Were this $6 for a sixer, Id be pleased to keep it on hand, but at FFF prices, I expect more.
Clear gold with a thin white head.  Well balanced, heavy malt flavor.  Pretty boring beer, which is a disappointment for me from Three Floyds because I love most of their stuff.
eh... too much malt for me. lah lah lah lah lah filling up the space lah lah lah lah. i hate that i have to actually type something.
Bottle courtesy of yjb.  Pours copper with a thin white head.  Smells of straw, some skunk (literally), matly.  Tastes of dry malt with some citrussy qualities.

22-oz bottle received via trade with tjthresh.  Pours hazy yellow with a small, fizzy, white head that quickly diminishes, spare lacing.  Aroma is heavy malt (meal, cereal, hay, straw), average hops (grass, herbs), heavy yeast (sweat, horse blanket, earth) with notes of corn and butter.

Bottle.  Clear light straw color with a thin white head.  Clean light malt aroma, light spice.  Moderate thickness and carbonation.  Taste is mostly desne light malts and a slight sweetness.  A bit sweet for a Helles.

Clear gold. Small creamy white head. Crisp, grainy malt and floral, earthy, and bitter hops. Id like more hops- fragrant and light, a drier finish, also. Medium body, balanced, real easy to drink. Decent.

I forgot. This is my 200th tasting. Poured from a bomber. Cloudy, light golden amber color. An overall maltiness surrounded by hints of yeast, grain and lemongrass with a nice hoppy finish. Well balanced, but a pretty boring style to begin with. 3F did the most they could with it.

22 ounce bottle
Pours hazy straw yellow with a short lived snow white head
Strong noble hop aroma, and lots of pilsner malt, grainy scent.
Im tasting a corny pilsner malt sweetness, with a smidge or hop flavor and bitterness.
Medium body.  Above average amount of carbonation.  A bit oily.
I dont know what folks are looking for here.  I mean, its a helles.  One of the most straight forward beers you can get.  Most will not get the high marks that and imperial stout or IIPA.  This is a fine beer.

22 oz bomber.  Pours a light hazy yellow lemon juice color with a small white head.  Aroma of zesty lemon, wheat and hops.  Taste is zesty lemony, watery and slightly grainy.  Weak effort from 3Floyds.

Another bottle from the kabose lover himself, Smitty boy.  Thanks again.  Pours out a light gold color with no head at all.  Smell is sweet and somewhat hoppy, but it lacks something.. not sure what.  Taste is weird, sweet, not hoppy at all, and just almost flat tasting.  To me this beer tastes like you ate a handful of European hops, drank 4 bombers of Gumball head, pissed in a bottle, capped it, and called it Gorch Fock.  I come to expect alot from FFF, as do most people (I believe), and for them to release something like this is just disappointing, and it hurts the wallet.  Sean left the sticker on this, presumably so I could be in shock.  10 bucks?  ok, whatever I am sick of the FFF is expensive argument too, but for 10 bucks I would buy Dreadnaught all day before even considering this.  The label is pretty sweet though.  Labels dont make the beer though.  Also, for 10 dollars I would expect more than Gumballhead after it was run through a bladder.

Yellow-gold pour with short, frothy white head. Aroma is pilsner-like, notes of grass and lemon and hints of bready malts. The flavor is lightly to moderately sweet and lightly bitter. There is a light flavor of citrus in the background. Nice texture  crisp and comfortably carbonated. A quiet and tasty beer from Three Floyds, but at $10 a bomber, this is overpriced. Great Lakes Dortmunder Gold offers lots more bang for the buck in this style.

$10 for a 4.5% beer? Yeah FFF! Pours a honey orange color with a small white head.  The nose smells rather beery, with light grassy hops and lots of pilsen malt.  Drinks really crisp, with more grass and pine hops dominating.  Finishes dry.  A nice beer, but come on guys.  Put in a sixer for $7.99 and Id drink it all year long.

Bottle purchased for 9.49 in Chicago. Pours a pale golden with very lively carbonation bubbles and a rocky white head. Aroma of hay, doughy bread, dried leafy herbs, and even some lemon. Medium to light bodied with a slight thin texture. Initial flavor of sweet biscuit and pils that transitions to a grassy and leafy hop middle. Crisp finish with some slight citrus accents. Overall, the flavors are very soft on the palate. Decent, and very refreshing. I drank this along with a Great Lakes Dortmunder Gold. The Great Lakes had a bit more depth in the malt profile, and was a bit more solid. I hate to jump on the FFF price complaint bandwagon, but this stuff is WAY overpriced. Great Lakes is 7.99 a six, this is 9.49 per 22 ounce.

Bomber thanks to Axilla.  Pours a typical light gold, moslty clear and a thin white head.  Aroma is herbal noble hops (wow no amarillo?!)  earthy, light bready pils mlats as well- doughy with a wierd tart tanginess.  Good bready malt flavor with some grassiness, earthy and spicy hops- and a decent clean cirsp hop  finish with a bit of fruity esters.  Not as clean or crisp as could be and just doesnt match up to the great german Helles examples.

Bottle from EithCubes - Thanks!  Pours a light gold color with just a bit of haziness, medium white head.  Nose is light and malty with a bit of wheat.  Tastes of wheat, malt, just a bit of citrus, and a twinge of apple juice.  May not be a great brew by 3F, but it sure is fun to cheer Gorch Fock!

Bottle: Pours a lightly misty yellow color with a quickly dissipating head. The nose is a bit herby with some husk and malt. Some wheat and funk melds with the yeast. The flavor is citrusy, with some syrupy wheat and a crisp hoppy bitter note. Fairly odd and thin for 3 floyds. The  finish is grassy and light. Eh. Good for a helles.

Bottle pours a hazy light golden with a huge foamy whiye head.   Lighht pale malt aroma.  Honey and a bit of stale cardboard.  Light and sweet honey and cornflakes.  Lively carbonation and a slighty UK hop bite.
Thanks to Jake65 for sharing this one.

22 oz bottle. Pours a nice light golden color with a small white head. Aroma of hops, malt and bread dough. The taste is crisp with a light citrus and wheat overtone. Light, dry and refreshing. Extremely smooth and easy to drink.  Has a slight hop bittterness in the tasty finish. Very nice and I guess I am a little surprised that there arent more higher ratings of this beer than there are.

Poured a dark golden color with a small, white head that left light lacing on the glass.  Aroma of toasty dough, light floral hops, and grainy malts.  Taste of more toasty dough, dry, with a bit of citrus, and perhaps even some corn?  Overall, not bad, just not on par with other 3Fs beers ive had. Thanks John!
22oz bottle shared courtesy of axilla. Poured a medium to deep and cloudy golden color with a small sizzed white head. Aromas and tastes of grass, grainy, floral and light citrus. Thinner body.
Poured hazy golden orange with a smaller bubbly white head.  Aroma was grassy, pilsner malt, cereal grains and floral notes.  Flavor of sweet cereal grains and some citrus.

(22 oz. bottle via trade with <A HREF=http://www.ratebeer.com/ViewUser.asp?UserID=3 target=blank>EithCubes, thanks Mike!) Pours hazy pale yellow with two fingers of white head. Aroma of honeyish malt. Mouthfeel smooth, refreshing, lightly prickly, dryish finish. Flavor is fairly reserved - honey, light hay. As it warms there is some breadiness and a very light citrus note in finish. Light bitter bite from fore through finish. Pretty good, could be a bit meatier.

Bomber pours a pale yellow body with a small white head. Aroma is simple, with grainy pale malts, floral hops, and a hint of honey and lemon. Light to light medium body with crisp carbonation. Taste is grainy sweet malt kissed by a soft hop bitterness that is lemony, floral, and slightly spicy. Tastes more like a good German kolsh than a helles. I really like this one. It would make a fine session brew if it were more affordable.

bomber. apricot colored clean and calm looking beer. little if any head. low and mellow grainy aroma has a citrus kiss.  crisp clean and balanced. easy drinking simple but elegant lager. let me just comment that all the hype must have gone to these guys heads. if lagunitas and bear republic can release top notch high quality beers for under $4 and $5, then why does this average should-be-in-a-sixer-for-$6.99  beer cost $9.99 a bomber?! frankly this kind of gouging is rubbing me the wrong way and i dont care how good dark lord is, ill drink something else.

650 ml. bomber bottle, no freshness date, Im not sure what the picture on the label is trying to say, homage to departed whalers? Oh well, sampled in a pilsener glass.

Not completely clear, there is a slight hazy towards the top, golden lager color, large frothy, foamy white head that slowly dissipates into a thin creamy foam lacing, nothing in the way of laced sticking.

Aromas of musty grains, sweet pale malts and lemony, flowery hops, a simple nose, but effective.

Smooth medium body, I could have used a little more carbonation for an airy creaminess that first rate Munich Helles lagers have. Musty honey grains with a light sweet fruitiness. Lemony, herbal leafy hops that are mildly bitter, turn a soft, delicate spicy at the end. Semi-dry grainy finish, a little spiciness linger on the tongue.

True to the style, but not in the upper echelon of Munich Helles Lagers, a near miss.

UPDATED: JUL 25, 2009 Straw with light, creamy head / Grain and honey nose / Medium body, sweet and creamy, good finish / Floral, perfumey flavors of grain and honey, with toasty, cookie finish / Nice balance of body, flavor and finish.

22 oz bomber thanks to xnoxhatex for supplying this.  Pours a hazy yellow with a wispy head.  Nose is typical of helles, at least an old bottle of helles.  Very grainy like old malt.  Thin bodied those grainy flavors a little lemon.  Very un-fff.  I would have thought they would have done an extreme hopped up version or at least a decent helles.   .... my guess is either this is a lot better on tap/really fresh ... or people are rating on namesake.

$8.99 a bomber from Archer Liquors.  Hazy golden yellow with a small white head, fading to a ring within seconds.  Aroma has some sweet corn and grain, and some light grassy hops.  Flavor is much the same only more corny notes are apparent.  Moderate sweetness with no discernible hop presence.  Low carbonation with a watery body.  Dortmunder Gold rocks this ones socks off.  This beer sucks for two reasons.  One, 3F brews are supposed to be good, and this is subpar at best.  Two, if they want to make a crappy beer, put a crappy price tag on it--not almost ten bucks.

text: Not my usual style of beer, and from the color, I expected it to be tasteless, but I was wrong. A lot of flavor for a lager, very drinkable and refreshing. Picked it up last night in a bomber bottle at the Maproom.

Bomber purchased at the brewery with the actual more reasonable FFF price of $5.  Cloudy yellow with small white head.  Lots of grain in the aroma with some spicy hop notes.  Flavor was pretty bland with no hop presence whatsoever, very unappealing.  Body was thin and watery.  Very macro in consistency  and uncharacteristic of a three floyds brew and I think the first that I really havent liked from them.

22oz bottle thanks to xnoxhatex for breaking this out. pours hazed yellow with pretty much no head. nose is very grainy and corn smelling. flavor is very adjuncty and grainy, with some hints of lemon. very watery feel to it. wheres the hops? wheres the micro-brewed character? well its not here. I cant even believe this is a fff brew. its horrible.

I kind of regret paying the FFF premium for this but a three floyds lager caught my interest.  An interesting beer.  pale yellow color, floral hops in the aroma.  taste is slightly fruity with a fair amount of body.  I enjoyed this but definately not worth the price, I do hope that they continue to bottle more seasonals though, especially if they continue to show up in my neighborhood

On tap at FFF.  Yellowy lagery golden without much of any of a white head (ring around the glass)  Peppery light hops over a bit of corn (?).  A bit of strawberry with some hay thrown in.  Light refreshing, crisp body with some carbonation.  Balanced.  Liberal peppery hops.  A bit of fruit.  Corny plain Jane malt.  Not bad, but not the most clean brew from these guys.
Very floral. You stick your nose in the beer and think: damn, thats a lager? Close to  a beer brewed in Germany. Very nice. Normally, I wouldnt drink a lager.

Bomber.  Poured a clear paler, yet bright golden with just the faintest dusting of white head.  The aroma was quite sweet overall with bread, honey, and milder citrus fruits as the major players.. floral and hay-like notes accent from the well-executed hop additions.  The flavor had a dry bready base paired with sweet honey.. lemon zest, drier floral notes, white pepper, and cloves (the spices really kick in at the finish).  Lighter-bodied, well-carbonated, dry, and refreshing on the palate.. solid balance.

A crystalline deep golden pour leaves the bottle with a bit of chill haze. Medium-high carbonation forms a tall white head that rapidly and fully recedes. The body looks more substantial than a Helles of traditional origins. The aroma is grassy with moderate lightly toasted grain and abundant unrefined cereal malts. Light fresh and wet hay/straw notes increase in potency with every degree of warmth. Star Thistle honey notes create a near-tangible link between malt and Eastern European noble hop nuances. The nose is very sweet and eludes to a tangy sweet flavor, well see if that holds true. The flavor is filled with buttery sweet malts a medium and very balanced expression of grain, supported by ample and genuine hop bitterness. Light pepper and very low astringency and acidity lend to mostly refreshing feel. Herb butter and spicy yeast arrive late. The mouthfeel is lowly carbonated and velvety, but too oily and weighty to feel refreshing, medium bodied and inconsistent. This is very drinkable but too muddled and filmy. The finish is grassy and soft, light bitterness and lighter acidity lingering, bitterness and peppery spice building long after the last sip.

Pours light golden with a fully receding white head. Aroma of honey malt, bready, cereal malt, and white grape. Taste is bready, lager yeast, grainy, clean fermentation. Mouthfeel is medium bodied with soft carbonation.

Bottle.  Have been holding onto this on for about two weeks, and I dont know why exactly...oh, right, a steep $10 / bomber.  Nose is malty, of the truly German type (slightly peppery and spicy), mixing bread and grass and gentle bg hops.  Very authentic smelling.  Clear, pale yellow pour with no visible carbonation and a fizzy, soapish white head.  Taste is all about the pale malt, and this sucker is loaded with it, spilling over with it, finally finishing in a cascade of bread and grass and lemon.  Spicy yeast and superb hopcit.  Dry, bready aftertaste.  Medium-fullish, quaffable body.  Enormously enjoyable and refreshing.  Nice low abv for FFF, too, earning this one top-notch status for summer sessions.  Rating this seems to be a bit of a tough call; I think more of you would be scoring this in the high 3s if you werent still grumbling about how goddamn expensive it is.  Notice I went with "high 3s"; this is no masterpiece, but an excellent brew and a potentially best-of-show Helles.

bottle.  hazy golden pour with rising bubbles to thin head.  light aroma rich malts, yeast and mild fruit.  light body.  grainy mouth, baked bread, some lemon.  dry finish.  well balanced.  nothing exciting.

UPDATED: JUN 13, 2008 Pour outta the bottle is a hazy yellow with a small white head.  Aroma is somewhat bready with some mild malts.  Flavor is just ok.  Some small amounts of malts and finishes bitter.  Nothing really great and damn expensive.

On tap @ the Brew pub: Pours a clear gold with a white head. Aroma, bready, yeast, spice, some wheat, and a hint of corn. Flavor, some corn, yeasty, doughy, some pale malts. Light refreshing, pretty solid beer.
Amazing commercial description. Clear golden. Aroma is strong bread, some grass, hay. Medium to light bodied. Very drinkable. Surprisingly enjoyable.

On tap at Three Floyds Brewpub, and served in a pint glass.  This beer poured a clear, golden color with a small, beige head.  The aroma was made up of bread, very light pine, and some lemony citrus notes.  The flavor was also very mild and included light bready yeast and citrus.  The mouthfeel was light and had a small dose of carbonation.  A solid representation of the style.  Worth a try.
UPDATED: AUG 17, 2007 On tap at brewpub a light bodied lager golden in color with a crisp refreshing citrus flavor and a good summer beer.CHEERS!

Draft @ the brewpub.  Translucent orange in color with a pocked gray head, persistently creamy throughout the experience.  Fresh, aromatic wet hops, sourdough crust, honey wheat bread and lemon shortbread cookies.  Heartily moderate flavor, rolling over to light crescent roll yeast.  Lemon biscotti sweetness rivals fresh hops, with the latter tipping the boat towards one of the more pine indoctrinated renditions in the genre.  Medium-to-light palate feel while maintaining a fun, active and personable persona.  Some pils malt similarities to align itself within the helles parameters.  Finishes with sourdough, herbal butter and a slightly bitter kiss.  Enjoyable, easy drinker.

This beer arrives in a light golden color wearing a good thick head.  This thick head dissolves slowly leaving in its wake a substantial amount of lacing on the side of glass.  It presents a sour, nutty, and hoppy aroma to the sent glands.  The mouth welcomes this smooth thin mixture.  The taste is a mild blend of Brazil nuts and hops, but unfortunately this taste is disrupted by a slight metallic presence that can be detected in the background.
Draft at 3F. A nice straw amber color. Taste is some floral hops along with grass and dough. Eh. Nothing more to say.
draft @ brewery. Pours a dark golden color with a decent white head. Lightly floral and doughy with some malt. Taste is Lightly bitter and doughy, with some sweet malt notes.
GTM. Dry lager aroma with some bitterness evident. Huge, white head. Gold in color. Bitter afterbite. Very nice palate. Smooth. A great example of the style.

Golden with coppery highlights with a large head that left decent lace on my plastic cup. Mildly orange, herbal and a little soapy in aroma. Flavor was moderately bitter with light acidity and citric to finish. Soft & creamy mouthfeel. Started forgettable but got more memorable after a couple more.
<font size=-4>On tap at <a href=http://www.ratebeer.com/Places/ShowPlace.asp? Floyds Brewing Company, Munster, IN<font size=-1>

On tap at the brewery.  Clear golden color with a big white head that left decent lacing.  Light citrus hop nose.  Light body.  This has the characteristic Three Floyds hop strength that left a little hop burn on the tongue.  Just hopped to hell for the style.  Tastey.

UPDATED: JUL 5, 2013 Re-rate March 2013, from bottle. Hazy, light orange body, medium off-white head. Skunky nose with biscuit and herbs, wheaty and spicy. Crackery, biscuity body with peppery, leafy, spicy hops. Complex and refreshing. I liked this quite a bit this time, served properly.

5/4/2005: Sampled this from its plastic cup in my in-and-out Dark Lord release visit.  Not necessarily to style, this poured a hazy light orangish yellow color, topped by a medium off-white head.  The body was quite grassy-hoppy, with some pine and a sweet, bready, lightly tangy malt backbone.  Quaffable, yet displayed typical house character.  I wasnt impressed or disappointed, but I was content. 7-3-7-3-14 (3.4).

On tap at the brewery.Clear piss yellow with a shitload of fine bubbled head.Lots of yeast and malts here.Teast,corn,farm smell and for some reason alot of bitterness,can it be the hops ??Thin and to much "farm" for me.

Not a big fan of the style but this was pretty good.  From the tap at the brewery.  Golden amber body with a frothy white head.  Nose was herbal, hoppy, grassy, citrusy.  Nice and complex and rewarding in itself.  Nice feel in the mouth.  Smooth.  The flavor was well-balanced with good parts malts and hops.  Not a traditional respresentation of the style, which is probably why I liked it.  Very drinkable.

Big grassy nose, really refreshing, Grassy bitterness and pretzelly maltiness.  Smooth, long bitter finish. I drank some while listening to the band Gorch Fock on my iPod, which certainly enhanced the experience.  Great gig poster on the Three Floyds wall, as well.  Think grassy Helles vs Three Floyds. Think Shellac vs Butthole Surfers.

Clear Golden body with a foamy, rocky white head.   Great aromas.  Mildy malty, with hints of sourdough, grass, and classic Three Floyds citrus.  Well balanced flavors.  Rich with malty flavors and dry, herbal hop notes.  Citrus was present throughout, but never overwhelming or up front.  It just kind of lingers in the back.  This stuff is dangerously drinkable.

Very clear and golden with a great pils-type head. A nice grassy/spicy hoppy lager with a thirst quenching bitterness in the finish. For those interested in style, this is really too low in gravity to be a helles, too malty and over bittered--definitely an American take on the style. I wont take off for it but I just thought I might point it out.
On tap at the brewwery. Nose is mostly hoppy with just a bit of malts or grains. The taste is hops and vegitations. Overall quite drinkable and pleasant.

On tap: Golden hue with some head and good lace. The nose has grassy and herbal hops character, twangy fruit esters, bready malts, and a bit mineral component. The taste starts with a nice crisp bitterness and balanced malty background. An acidic like twang and lingering bitters add depth of palate. The feel is average but works within the style. A good version, a Floyds slightly hopped up take. I liked it a lot.

Light yellow pour with a decent white head. The aroma has a lot of piney/earthy hops and the flavor doesnt have much malt to carry it as a Helles. A little disappointed with the amount of bitterness present.
pale cloudy yellow, white head.  piney aroma, nice bitter flavor.  great aftertaste that lingers awhile.  i like it.
Draft at the brewery. Flavour and aroma are mostly piney with a hint of caramel.
Draft at Floyds.  Very light hoppy aroma.  Cloduy yellow with a white head.  Nice and hoppy pine and citrus.  Refreshing after a tasting stronger stuff.
Poured out a hazy yellow with descent head.   Nice amounts of 3F hop, malt, with some undertoning caramel.  I believe its my first of the style, enjoyable.

#10 rating of this beer to put it on the list.  Aroma is grassy hops, caramel and toasted malts.  Appearance is tiny particles suspended in a piss yellow body.  Thick rocky head with excellent lacing and head retention.  First piss looking beer Ive given a 4 to on appearance. :)  Flavor is herbal and grassy hops, caramel, and something indescribable.  Palate is sweet with a medium mouth feel.  Excellent!  Pick this one up when it gets bottled (I hope it does).

Draft, at 3Fs. A suprise for a Floyds beer. Yes, its incredibly hopped, but with German hops. Color is deep yellow, if I can call it that. A thin, lacy head; a fine helles malt profile with the Dortmunder hard water taste like a DAB. Pinprickly bubbles play well on the tongue. Be sure to try this one in between scarfing down Dark Lords.

On Tap- Pours a slighty hazy golden yellow color. Lots of lacing, small white head. Aroma of cardboard, stale bread, plastic, wheat. Flavor is pine needles, and wheat. A very hoppy Helles (go figure) Thanks to TannerTavernBoys for this one.
A thin pale ale look to this beer.  The aroma is a little sweet and the head is average.  Smooth, sweet, and crisp taste that reminds me of most of the 3floyd beers with the hop touch.

On tap at the brewery. Brought a pint glass with to the brewery. Yellowish with an off white head. The aroma is almost like noble hops, but the brewmaster said it was something crazy like warrior? Taste is slightly bitter, almost like a traditional euro lager. A nice example of this style, though certainly not within BJCP guidelines.

This Alpha Dort is absolutely wonderful.  Great lively carbonation, surprisingly impressive hopping, sweet malt hints (livelier as it warms) and a wonderful  bitter aftertaste that makes me want another one immediately...and so I think I shall.

UPDATED: JUL 4, 2005 3F should be bottling this brew for the Summer months.  Interesteing northwestern hopping to a Dortmunder, and I highly approve.
